byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Berlin.

abstract: Gunter Grass, Nobel Prize-winning German novelist and social critic, dies at age 87; long seen as Germany's moral conscience due to way his work pushed Germans to reckon with ugly aspects of their history, particularly World War II, Grass stunned literary world in 2006 by revealing that he was a member of Waffen-SS during war.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Grass was the novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his country’s moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been in the Waffen-SS.

headline.main: Günter Grass Dies at 87; Writer Pried Open Germany’s Past but Hid His Own
headline.print_headline: Günter Grass, 87, Dies; Pried Open German Past While Hiding His Own

snippet: Mr. Grass was the novelist, social critic and Nobel Prize winner whom many called his country’s moral conscience but who stunned Europe when he revealed in 2006 that he had been in the Waffen-SS.
